We shall have to strike out in new directions
here. We shall have to create those environ¬
ments in which learning can occur differently.
We shall have to create those settings in which
each element, including the student population,
contributes to the task of achieving successes,
and that every element is designed to make its
contribution to that end.
"Software" materials, therefore, must be designed
differently today, and needless to say, different¬
ly to meet our needs. The Educational Technolo¬
gist, that new breed of educator, has developed
an entire spectrum of valuable teaching aids,
from "Dial Access" devices, to the simple hand¬
held "Calculator." We must enlist his aid in re¬
solving the educational problems we will be facing.
Criticism and failures notwithstanding, 0E0 pro¬
grams are reaching more people today than they
reached in 1964, or 1965. By 1970, it is likely
that we will have touched, in some way or other,
the life of every family living in poverty in the
nation.
